rRBMTx-y6.memHandModelNotes: Uses both deep and shallow waters (NatureServe 2005).  Primarily aquatic use hydro for range.  Terrestrial habitat is selected for nest sites however can select all pixels within hydro buffer. . Amy Silvano 8jul05

references.B72ERN01NAUS: Ernst, C. H., and R. W. Barbour. 1972. Turtles of the United States. Univ. Press of Kentucky, Lexington. x + 347 pp.
references.B94ERN01NAUS: Ernst, C. H., R. W. Barbour, and J. E. Lovich. 1994. Turtles of the United States and Canada. Smithsonian Institution Press, Washington, D.C. xxxviii + 578 pp.

references.B95WIL01NCGP: Wilson, L. A. 1995. The Land Manager's Guide to the amphibians and reptiles of the South. Chapel Hill, NC: The Nature Conservancy.

habitat_description:
The range of the razor-backed musk turtle extends from Mississippi, Alabama, eastern Texas, Oklahoma, and Arkansas. The majority of the populations coincide with the Gulf Coastal Plain (Ernst and Barbour 1989).

This benthic species is known to burrow in or using soil, decaying logs, and leaf litter. Hibernation takes place in holes found near overhanging banks or under rocks at the bottom of water bodies (Ernst and Barbour 1972). Its preferred habitats include big and medium sized rivers, low gradient streams, and deep and shallow pools or ponds. Riparian zones are restricted to forested wetlands only. Major characteristics of its habitat include slow moving currents of rivers and streams; swamps have abundant aquatic vegetation and basking sites, as well as soft, muddy bottoms (Natureserve.org).

Vegetation found in riparian forested wetland.
